I52PART 2700_ORGANIZATION AND FUNCTIONS
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262700.1General statement.
I262700.2Organization.
I262700.3Functions.

Q04I21T5Authority:  T15 U.S.C. 301, 552; 7 CFR 2.81.
Q04I21T5Source:  T147 FR 39128, Sept. 7, 1982, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2700.1
I89General statement.
I11This part is issued in accordance with 5 U.S.C. 552(a) to provide guidance for the general public as to the organization and functions of the Office of Information Resources Management.

I80�1A2700.2
I89Organization.
I11The Office of Information Resources Management (OIRM) was established on January 12, 1982. Delegations of authority to the Director, OIRM appear at 7 CFR 2.81. The organization is comprised of five headquarters divisions, an administrative staff and three computer centers to serve the Department. The organization is headed by the Director or, in the Director's absence, by the Deputy Director or, in the absence of both, by the Director's desginee.

I80�1A2700.3
I89Functions.
I11(a) T3Director.G1T1 Provides executive direction for OIRM. Develops and recommends Departmental information resources management principles, policies, and objectives; develops and disseminates Departmental information resources management standards, guidelines, rules, and regulations necessary to implement approved principles, policies, and programs; designs, develops, implements, and revises systems, processes, work methods, and techniques to improve the management of information resources and the operational effectiveness of the Department; provides telecommunications and automated data processing services to the Department's agencies and staff offices.
I11(b) T3Deputy Director.G1T1 Assists the Director and, in the absence of the Director, serves as the Acting Director.
I11(c) T3Administrative Management Staff.G1T1 Provides support for agency management regarding budget, accounting, personnel, and other administrative matters.
I11(d) T3Planning Division.G1T1 Defines, develops, guides, and administers the Department's long-range planning process for information resources.
I11(e) T3Information Management Division.G1T1 Develops policy, standards and guidelines for collection, protection, access, use and management of information.
I11(f) T3Review and Evaluation Division.G1T1 Reviews and evaluates information resources programs and activities of Department agencies and staff offices for conformance with plans, policies, and standards.
I11(g) T3Agency Technical Services Division.G1T1 Advises and consults with and assists Department agencies and staff offices on activities related to the development and implementation of automated information systems.
I11(h) T3Operations and Telecommunications Division.G1T1 Coordinates the development and implementation of programs for ADP and telecommunications resource planning within Departmental computer centers and the National Finance Center, and for the acquisition and use of Department-wide telecommunications facilities and services.
I11(i) T3Departmental Computer Centers.G1T1 The following centers provide ADP facilities and services to agencies and staff offices of the Department.
I11(1) Washington Computer Center, 14th and Independence Ave., SW., Rm. S�09107�09South, Washington, DC 20250.
I11(2) Fort Collins Computer Center, 3825 E. Mulberry Street (P.O. Box 1206), Fort Collins, CO 80524.
I11(3) Kansas City Computer Center, 8930 Ward Parkway (P.O. Box 205), Kansas City, MO 64141.

I52PART 2710_AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262710.1General statement.
I262710.2Public inspection and copying.
I262710.3Indexes.
I262710.4Initial request for records.
I262710.5Appeals.
Q02I26T5T4Appendix A to PartG1T5 2710T4_List of AddressesG1T5

Q04I21T5Authority:  T15 U.S.C. 301, 552; 7 CFR 1.1�091.16.
Q04I21T5Source:  T147 FR 39129, Sept. 7, 1982, unless otherwise noted.

�34�I80�1A2710.1
I89General statement.
I11This part is issued in accordance with 7 CFR 1.4 of the U.S. Department of Agriculture regulations governing the availability of records (7 CFR 1.1�091.16 and Appendix A) under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. 552). The Department's regulations, as supplemented by the regulations in this part, provide guidance for any person wishing to request records from the Office of Information Resources Management (OIRM).

I80�1A2710.2
I89Public inspection and copying.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) required that each agency make certain kinds of records available for public inspection and copying.
I11(b) T3Procedure.G1T1 Persons wishing to gain access to OIRM records should contact the Information Access & Disclosure Officer by writing to the address shown in 2710.4(b)(2).

I80�1A2710.3
I89Indexes.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) also required that each agency maintain and make available for public inspection and copying current indexes providing identifying information for the public with regard to any records which are made available for public inspection and copying.
I11(b) T3Procedure.G1T1 Persons wishing to get an index may contact the division or center that maintains the records. Publication of these indexes as a separate document is unnecessary and impractical.

I80�1A2710.4
I89Initial request for records.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 The Information Access and Disclosure Officer is authorized to:
I11(1) Grant or deny requests for OIRM records.
I11(2) Make discretionary releases of OIRM records when it is determined that the public interests in disclosure outweigh the public and/or private ones in withholding.
I11(3) Reduce or waive fees to be charged where determined to be appropriate.
I11(b) T3Procedure.G1T1 Persons wishing to request records from the Office of Information Resources Management may do so as follows:
I11(1) T3How.G1T1 Submit each initial request for OIRM records as prescribed in 7 CFR 1.3(a).
I11(2) T3Where.G1T1 Submit each initial request to the Information Access and Disclosure Officer, Office of Information Resources Management, USDA, 14th and Independence Ave., SW., Room 407�09W, Washington, DC 20250.

I80�1A2710.5
I89Appeals.
I11T3Procedure.G1T1 Any person whose initial request is denied in whole or in part may appeal that denial, in accordance with 7 CFR 1.3(e) and 1.7, to the Director, Office of Information Resources Management, by sending the appeal to the Information Access and Disclosure Officer, Office of Information Resources Management, USDA, 14th and Independence Ave., SW., Room 407�09W, Washington, DC 20250. The Director, Office of Information Resources Management, will make the determination on the appeal.

I52PART 2810_ORGANIZATION AND FUNCTIONS_OFFICE OF OPERATIONS
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262810.1General statement.
I262810.2Organization.
I262810.3Functions.

Q04I21T5Authority:  T15 U.S.C. 301 and 552; 7 CFR 2.76.
Q04I21T5Source:  T154 FR 52013, Dec. 20, 1989, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2810.1
I89General statement.
I11This part is issued in accordance with 5 U.S.C. 552(a) to provide guidance for the general public as to Office of Operations (OO) organization and functions.

I80�1A2810.2
I89Organization.
I11The Office of Operations (OO) was established January 12, 1982. Delegations of authority to the Director, OO, appear at 7 CFR 2.76. The organization is comprised of six divisions and one staff located at Department headquarters. Description of the functions of these organizational units are in the following section. The organization is headed by a Director.

I80�1A2810.3
I89Functions.
I11(a) T3Director.G1T1 Provides executive direction for OO. Develops and promulgates overall policies and provides general direction, leadership, oversight, and coordination of USDA management of procurement, real and personal property activities, mail and copier management. Provides executive services to the Office of the Secretary and operates activities providing consolidated USDA administrative functions and services.
I11(b) T3Deputy Director.G1T1 Assists the Director, and in the absence of the Director, serves as Acting Director.
I11(c) T3Administrative Unit.G1T1 Provides support for agency management regarding budget, accounting, personnel, and other administrative matters.
I11(d) T3Executive Services Division.G1T1 Provides executive services to the Office of the Secretary in travel arrangements, supplies, furnishings, communications, equipment, and records. Operates the central USDA DC imprest fund.
I11(e) T3Facilities Management Division.G1T1 Operates and maintains the USDA DC headquarters building complex, including headquarters parking. Oversees management and operation of USDA buildings nationwide, and provides DC area labor services.
I11(f) T3Mail and Reproduction Management Division.G1T1 Oversees USDA mail, copier, and duplicating programs. Operates DC area central activities in these areas.
I11(g) T3Personal Property Management Division.G1T1 Oversees USDA supply, motor vehicle, and personal property programs. Operates centralized warehouse and property rehabilitation facilities.
I11(h) T3Procurement Division.G1T1 Oversees USDA procurement programs. Operates centralized purchasing operations for ADP and Washington area activities.
I11(i) T3Real Property Management Division.G1T1 Oversees USDA real property management programs.


I95Pt. 2811
I52PART 2811_AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262811.1General statement.
I262811.2Public inspection and copying.
I262811.3Indexes.
I262811.4Initial requests for records.
I262811.5Appeals.
I262811.6Fee schedule.
Q02I26T5T4Appendix A to PartG1T5 2811T4_List of AddressesG1T5

Q04I21T5Authority:  T15 U.S.C. 301 and 552 (as amended); 7 CFR 1.3. 
Q04I21T5Source:  T154 FR 52014, Dec. 20, 1989, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2811.1
I89General statement.
I11This part is issued in accordance with 7 CFR 1.3 of the Department of Agriculture regulations governing the availability of records (7 CFR 1.1�091.23 and Appendix A) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. 552. The Department's regulations, as supplemented by the regulations in this part, provide guidance for any person wishing to request records from Office of Operations.

I80�1A2811.2
I89Public inspection and copying.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) requires that each agency maintain and make available for public inspection and copying certain kinds of records.
�40�I11(b) T3Procedure.G1T1 To gain access to OO records that are available for public inspection, contact the division that maintains them. See Appendix A, List of Addresses, for the location and hours of operation.

I80�1A2811.3
I89Indexes.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 15 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) also requires that each agency maintain and make available for public inspection and copying current indexes provided identifying information for the public with regard to any records which are made available for public inspection and copying. OO does not maintain any materials within the scope of these requirements.

I80�1A2811.4
I89Initial requests for records.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 The head of each OO division, each OO contracting officer, each OO leasing officer, and the OO FOIA officer is authorized to:
I11(1) Grant or deny requests for OO records.
I11(2) Make discretionary release of OO records when it is determined that the public interest in disclosure outweighs the public and/or private ones in withholding.
I11(3) Reduce or waive fees to be charged where determined to be appropriate.
I11(4) Refer a request to the OO FOIA Officer for determination. 
I11(b) T3Procedures.G1T1 Persons wishing to request records from the Office of Operations may do so as follows:
I11(1) How. Submit each initial request for OO records as prescribed in 7 CFR 1.6.
I11(2) Where. Submit each initial request to the head of the unit that maintains the records. See Appendix A, List of Addresses. Contact the FOIA Officer for guidance as needed. Or, submit the request to the FOIA Officer for forwarding to the proper officials: FOIA Officer, Office of Operations, USDA, Room 134�09W Administration Building, 14th & Independence Avenue SW., Washington, DC 20250.

I80�1A2811.5
I89Appeals.
I11T3Procedure.G1T1 Any person whose initial request is denied in whole or in part may appeal that denial, in accordance with 7 CFR 1.6(e) and 1.8, to the Director, Office of Operations, USDA, Room 113�09W Administration Building, 14th & Independence Avenue SW., Washington, DC 20250.

I80�1A2811.6
I89Fee schedule.
I11Department regulations provide for a schedule of reasonable standard charges for document search and duplication. See 7 CFR 1.2(b). Fees to be charged are set forth in 7 CFR part 1, subpart A, appendix A.

I52PART 2812_DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE GUIDELINES FOR THE DONATION OF EXCESS RESEARCH EQUIPMENT UNDER 15 U.S.C. 3710(i)
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262812.1Purpose.
I262812.2Eligibility.
I262812.3Definitions.
I262812.4Procedures.
I262812.5Restrictions.
I262812.6Title.
I262812.7Costs.
I262812.8Accountability and recordkeeping.
I262812.9Disposal.
I262812.10Liabilities and losses.
Q02I26T5T4Appendix A to PartG1T5 2812_T4Gift/Acceptance Agreement: Educational Institution or NonProfit Organization and the United States Department of AgricultureG1T5 

Q04I21T5Authority: T15 U.S.C. 301.
Q04I21T5Source: T160 FR 34456, July 3, 1995, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2812.1 
I89Purpose.
I11This part sets forth the procedures to be utilized by USDA agencies and laboratories in the donation of excess research equipment to educational institutions and non-profit organizations for the conduct of technical and scientific education and research activities as authorized by 15 U.S.C. 3710(i). Title to excess research equipment donated pursuant to 15 U.S.C. 3710(i), shall pass to the donee.

I80�1A2812.2 
I89Eligibility.
I11Eligible organizations are educational institutions or non-profit organizations involved in the conduct of technical and scientific educational and research activities.

I80�1A2812.3
I89Definitions.
I11(a) T3Cannibalization.G1T1 The dismantling of equipment for parts to repair or enhance other equipment. The residual is reported for disposal. Cannibalization is only authorized if the property value is greater when cannibalized than retention in the original condition.
I11(b) T3Education-related Federal equipment.G1T1 Equipment that is appropriate for educational purposes.
I11(c) T3Excess personal property.G1T1 Items of personal property no longer required by the controlling Federal agency. 
I11(d) T3Research equipment.G1T1 Federal property determined to be essential to conduct scientific or technical educational research.
I11(e) T3Technical and scientific education and research activities.G1T1 Non-profit tax exempt public educational institutions or government sponsored research organizations which serve to conduct technical and scientific education and research.

I80�1A2812.4
I89Procedures.
I11(a) Prior to receipt of excess personal property/equipment under this part, the donee shall enter into a gift/acceptance agreement with the donor agency. A copy of that agreement is attached as appendix A to this part.
I11(b) Each agency head will designate in writing an authorized official to approve donations of excess property/equipment under this part.
I11(c) Property targeted for donation under this part will first be screened as excess by USDA agencies through the Departmental Excess Personal Property Coordinator (DEPPC) using the PMIS/PROP system.
I11(d) Upon reporting property for excess screening, if the pertinent USDA agency has an eligible organization in mind for donation under this part, enter ``P.L. 102�09245'' in the note field. The property will remain in the excess system approximately 30�0945 days and, if no agency in USDA requests it during the excess cycle, DEPPC will send the agency a copy of the excess report stamped ``DONATION AUTHORITY TO THE HOLDING AGENCY IN ACCORDANCE WITH P.L. 102�09245.''
I11(e) Donations under this Part will be accomplished by preparing a Standard Form (SF) 122, ``Transfer Order-Excess Personal Property'' and a written justification statement (submitted by the recipient) explaining why the property is needed.
I11(f) The SF�09122 should be signed by both an authorized official of the agency and the Agency Property Management Officer. The following information should also be provided.
Q02
I11(1) Name and address of Donee Institution (Ship to)
�42�I11(2) Agency name and address (holding Agency)
I11(3) Location of property
I11(4) Shipping instructions (Donee contact person)
I11(5) Complete description of property, including acquisition amount, serial no., condition code, quantity, and agency order no.
I11(6) This statement needs to be added following property descriptions. ``The property requested hereon is certified to be used for the conduct of technical and scientific education and research activities. This donation is pursuant to the provisions of Pub. L. 102�09245.''
Q02
I11(g) Once the excess personal property/equipment is physically received, the donee is required to immediately return a copy of the SF�09122 to the donating agency indicating receipt of requested items. Cancellations should be reported to DEPPC so the property can be reported to the General Services Administration (GSA).
I21T5Note: T1The USDA agency shall send an informational copy of the transaction to GSA.

I80�1A2812.5 
I89Restrictions.
I11(a) The authorized official (see �1A2812.4(b)) will approve the donation of excess personal property/equipment in the following groups to educational institutions or nonprofit organizations for the conduct of technical and scientific educational and research activities.
c2,L2,i1,s25,r100  I95T4Eligible Groups
h1FSC group  h1Name
j
I0119DShips, Small Craft, Pontoons, and Floating Docks.
I0123DVehicles, Trailers and Cycles.
I0124DTractors.
I0137DAgricultural Machinery and Equipment.
I0143DPumps, Compressors.
I0148DValves.
I0158DCommunication, Detection, and Coherent Radiation Equipment.
I0159DElectrical and Electronic Equipment Components.
I0165DMedical, Dental, and Veterinary Equipment and Supplies.
I0166DInstruments and Laboratory Equipment.
I0167DPhotographic Equipment.
I0168DChemicals and Chemical Products.
I0170DGeneral Purpose Automatic Data Processing Equipment, Software Supplies, and Support Equipment.
I0174DOffice Machines and Visible Record Equipment.
e


I21T5Note: T1Requests for items in FSC Groups or Classes other than the above should be referred to the agency head for consideration and approval.
I11(b) Excess personal property/equipment may be donated for cannibalization purposes, provided the donee submits a supporting statement which clearly indicates that cannibalizing the requested property for secondary use has greater potential benefit than utilization of the item in its existing form.

I80�1A2812.6 
I89Title.
I11Title to excess personal property/equipment donated under this Part will automatically pass to the donee once the sponsoring agency receives the SF�09122 indicating that the donee has received the property.

I80�1A2812.7 
I89Costs.
I11Donated excess personal property/equipment is free of charge. However, the donee must pay all costs associated with packaging and transportation, unless the sponsoring agency has made other arrangements. The donee should specify the method of shipment.

I80�1A2812.8 
I89Accountability and recordkeeping.
I11USDA requires that property requested by a donee be placed into use by the donee within a year of receipt and used for at least 1 year thereafter. Donees must maintain accountable records for such property during this time period.

I80�1A2812.9 
I89Disposal.
I11When the property is no longer needed by the donee, it may be used in support of other Federal projects or sold and the proceeds used for technical and scientific education and research activities.

I80�1A2812.10 
I89Liabilities and losses.
I11USDA assumes no liability with respect to accidents, bodily injury, illness, or any other damages or loss related to excess personal property/equipment donated under this part. The donee is advised to insure or otherwise protect itself and others as appropriate.
S8002
�43�I95Pt. 2812, App. A
I85Appendix A to Part T12812_G1T5T4Gift/Acceptance Agreement: Educational Institution or NonProfit Organization and the United States Department of AgricultureG1T5
I21Gift/Acceptance Agreement (Agreement) between (USDA Agency) and (Educational Institution or NonProfit Organizations).
I21(1) T3Purpose.G1T1 The purpose of the Agreement is to establish a relationship between the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA Agency) and (Educational Institution or NonProfit Organization) concerning the transfer of excess research equipment to this educational institution or nonprofit organization for the conduct of technical and scientific education and research activities. Title of ownership transfers to the recipient.
I21(2) T3Authority.G1T1 Pub. L. 102�09245, Sec. 303, amended, Section 11 of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980, by adding subsection (i), Research Equipment, which provides that ``the Director of the laboratory, or the head of any Federal agency or department, may give research equipment that is excess to the needs of the laboratory, agency, or department to an educational institution or non-profit organization for the conduct of technical and scientific education and research activities.''
I21(3) T3Objectives and program elements.G1T1 This Agreement is intended to provide a mechanism for the transfer of excess research equipment from USDA to the (Educational Institution or Nonprofit Organization) in accordance with the procedures set out in the regulations implementing Pub. L. 102�09245.
I21(4) T3Management.G1T1 In order to enable close collaboration, it is agreed that the (Educational Institution or NonProfit Organization) will provide to (USDA Agency) an annual inventory listing of property acquired under Pub. L. 102�09245.
I21The (USDA Agency) and (Educational Institution or NonProfit Organization) will each identify a coordinator to implement this Agreement. These coordinators shall meet when necessary to review new Federal property regulations.
I21The coordinators shall seek to resolve any disputes concerning the Agreement through good faith discussions.
I21(5) T3Effective date and revision or termination.G1T1 The Agreement shall enter into effect upon signature and shall remain in effect for 3 years. It may be extended or amended by written agreement of the parties at any time prior to its expiration or termination. The Agreement may be terminated at any time upon 60 days written notice by either party to the other. The termination of the Agreement shall not affect the validity of any property transactions under the Agreement which were initiated prior to such termination.

I21The property coordinators for this Agreement are:

I52PART 2900_ESSENTIAL AGRICULTURAL USES AND VOLUMETRIC REQUIREMENTS_NATURAL GAS POLICY ACT
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262900.1General.
I262900.2Definitions.
I262900.3Essential agricultural uses.
I262900.4Natural gas requirements.
I262900.6Effective date.

Q04I21T5Authority:  T1Pub. L. 95�09621, Nov. 9, 1978.
Q04I21T5Source:  T144 FR 28786, May 17, 1979, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2900.1
I89General. 
I11Section 401(c) of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 (NGPA) requires the Secretary of Agriculture to determine the essential uses of natural gas, and to certify to the Secretary of Energy and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) the natural gas requirements, expressed either as volumes or percentages of use, of persons, or classes thereof, for essential agricultural uses in order to meet requirements of full food and fiber production. This rule covers establishments performing functions classed as essential agricultural uses whose natural gas supplies are distributed through the interstate pipeline systems even though such establishments may receive such gas directly from an intrastate pipeline or local distribution company. The rule provides to the Secretary of Energy (for purposes of Section 401(a) of the NGPA) and to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission the following certifications: 
I11(a) Essential agricultural T3usesG1T1 of natural gas, expressed as classes of establishments that use gas for essential agricultural purposes; and 
I11(b) Essential agricultural current T3requirementsG1T1 of natural gas, expressed as percentages of use. 

I80�1A2900.2
I89Definitions. 
I11(a) T3Full food and fiber productionG1T1 means the entire output of food and fiber produced for the domestic market, and for export, for building of reserves, and crops for soil building or conservation. This term also includes the processing of food and fiber into stable and storable products, and the maintenance of food quality after processing. 
I11(b) T3EstablishmentG1T1 means an economic unit, generally at a single physical location where business is conducted or where service or industrial operations are performed (for example, a factory, mill, store, mine, farm, sales office, or warehouse). (Note: This is the same definition used in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972 edition). 
I11(c) T3Essential Agricultural Use EstablishmentG1T1 means any Establishment, or the portion of an Establishment, which performs (or has the capability to perform) activities specified in �1A2900.3. 
I11(d) T3Current Natural Gas RequirementsG1T1 means the amount of natural gas required by an Essential Agricultural Use Establishment to perform the activities devoted to full food and fiber production. 
Q04
S8003I20(Pub. L. 95�09621, Nov. 8, 1979, 92 Stat. 3350, 15 U.S.C. 3301 T3et seq.G1T1)

I80�1A2900.4 
I89Natural gas requirements. 
I11For purposes of Section 401(c), NGPA, the natural gas requirements for each Essential Agricultural Use Establishment, whether such Essential Agricultural Use Establishment is in existence on the effective date of this rule or comes into existence thereafter, are certified to be 100 percent of Current Natural Gas Requirements.

I89Effective date. 
I11This rule shall become effective on May 14, 1979. 

I95Pt. 2901
I52PART 2901_ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES FOR ADJUSTMENTS OF NATURAL GAS CURTAILMENT PRIORITY
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I262901.1Purpose and scope.
I262901.2Definitions.
I262901.3Oral presentation.
I262901.4Interpretations.
I262901.5Modifications and rescissions.
I262901.6Exceptions and exemptions.
I262901.7Review of denials.
I262901.8Judicial review.
I262901.9Effective date.

Q04
�49�I21T5Authority:  T1Secs. 502, 507. Pub. L. 95�09621, 92 Stat. 3397, 3405, Nov. 9, 1978.
Q04I21T5Source:  T144 FR 55803, Sept. 28, 1979, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A2901.1
I89Purpose and scope.
I11The purpose of this part 2901 is to provide procedures for the making of certain adjustments to the Secretary of Agriculture's Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations in accordance with section 502(c) of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, in order to prevent special hardship, inequity, or an unfair distribution of burdens. The procedures in this part 2901 apply to any person seeking an interpretation of, modification of, rescission of, exception of, or exemption from the Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations in part 2900 of this chapter. 

I80�1A2901.2 
I89Definitions.
I11(a) T3PersonG1T1 means any individual, firm, sole proprietorship, partnership, association, company, joint venture or corporation.
I11(b) T3DirectorG1T1 means the Director of the Office of Energy, U.S. Department of Agriculture.
I11(c) T3SecretaryG1T1 means the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
I11(d) T3AdjustmentG1T1 means an interpretation, modification, rescission of, exception to or exemption from the Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations, part 2900 of this chapter. 
I11(e) T3NGPAG1T1 means the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, Pub. L. 95�09621.
I11(f) T3PetitionerG1T1 means any person seeking an adjustment under this part 2901.

I80�1A2901.3 
I89Oral presentation.
I11Any person seeking an adjustment under this part 2901 shall be given an opportunity to make an oral presentation of data, views and arguments in support of the request for an adjustment, provided that a request to make an oral presentation is submitted in writing with the request for the adjustment. An official of the Department of Agriculture shall preside at such oral presentation.

I80�1A2901.4 
I89Interpretations.
I11(a) T3Request for an interpretation.G1T1 (1) Any person seeking an interpretation of the Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations in part 2900 shall file a formal written request with the Director. The request should contain a full and complete statement of all relevant facts pertaining to the circumstances, act or transaction that is the subject of the request and to the action sought, and should state the special hardship, inequity, or unfair distribution of burdens that will be prevented by the interpretation sought and why the interpretation is consistent with the purposes of NGPA. The Director shall publish a notice in the T4Federal RegisterG1T1 advising the public that a request for an interpretation has been received and that written comments will be accepted with respect thereto, if received within 20 days of the notice. The T4Federal RegisterG1T1 notice will provide that copies of the request for interpretation from which confidential information has been deleted in accordance with paragraph (a)(2) of this section may be obtained from the petitioner.
I11(2) If the petitioner wishes to claim confidential treatment for any information contained in the request or other documents submitted under this part 2901, such person shall file together with the document a second copy of the document from which has been deleted the information for which such person wishes to claim confidential treatment. The petitioner shall indicate in the original document that it is confidential or contains confidential information and may file a statement specifying the justification for non-disclosure of the information for which non-disclosure is sought. The Director shall consider such requests, and subject to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. 552 and other applicable laws and regulations, shall treat such information as confidential.
I11(b) T3Investigations.G1T1 The Director may initiate an investigation of any statement in a request and utilize in his evaluation any relevant facts obtained in such investigation. The Director may accept submissions from third persons relevant to any request for interpretation provided that the petitioner �50�is afforded an opportunity to respond to all such submissions. In evaluating a request for interpretation, the Director may consider any other source of information.
I11(c) T3Applicability.G1T1 Any interpretation issued hereunder shall be issued on the basis of the information provided on the request, as supplemented by other information brought to the attention of the Director during the consideration of the request. The interpretation shall, therefore, depend for its authority on the accuracy of the factual statement and may be relied upon only to the extent that the facts of the actual situation correspond to those upon which the interpretation was based. 
I11(d) T3Issuance of an interpretation.G1T1 Upon consideration of the request for interpretation and other relevant information received or obtained by the Director, the Director may issue a written interpretation. A copy of the written interpretation shall be provided to FERC and the Secretary of Energy. Notice of the issuance of the written interpretation shall be published in the T4Federal Register.G1T1 The granting of a request for issuance of an interpretation shall be considered final agency action for purposes of judicial review under �1A2901.8.
I11(e) T3Denial of an interpretation.G1T1 An interpretation shall be considered denied for purpose of review of such denial under �1A2901.7 only if:
I11(1) The Director notifies the petitioner in writing that the request is denied and that an interpretation will not be issued; or
I11(2) The Director does not respond to a request for an interpretation, by (i) issuing an interpretation, or (ii) giving notice of when an interpretation will be issued within 45 days of the date of receipt of the request, or within such extended time as the Director may prescribe by written notice within the 45-day period.
I11(f) For purposes of this part 2901 the word T3interpretationG1T1 shall not be deemed to include a simple clarification of an actual or purported ambiguity in part 2900. The Director reserves the right to determine whether a request involves simple clarification and shall advise the requester of his decision.

I80�1A2901.5
I89Modifications and rescissions.
I11(a) T3Request for modification or rescission.G1T1 (1) Any person seeking a modification or a rescission of the Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations of part 2900 shall file a formal written request with the Director. The request shall contain a full and complete statement of all relevant facts pertaining to the circumstance, act or transaction that is the subject of the request and to the action sought. The request should state the special hardship, inequity or unfair distribution of burdens that will be prevented by making the modification or rescission.
I11(2) If the petitioner wishes to claim confidential treatment for any information contained in the request or other documents submitted under this part 2901, such person shall file together with the document a second copy of the document from which has been deleted the information for which such person wishes to claim confidential treatment. The petitioner shall indicate in the original document that it is confidential or contains confidential information and may file a statement specifying the justification for non-disclosure of the information for which non-disclosure is sought. The Director shall consider such requests, and subject to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. 552 and other applicable laws and regulations, shall treat such information as confidential.
I11(3) The request shall be filed as a petition for rulemaking and treated in accordance with the procedures, as applicable, of 7 CFR part 1, subpart B.
I11(b) T3Institution of rulemaking.G1T1 Upon consideration of the request for modification or rescission and other relevant information received or obtained by the Director, the Director may institute rulemaking proceedings in accordance with the Administrative Procedures Act 5 U.S.C. 551 T3et seq.G1T1 and applicable regulations. 
I11(c) T3Denial of a modification or rescission.G1T1 If the Director (1) denies the request for modification or rescission in writing by notifying the petitioner that he does not intend to institute rulemaking proceedings as proposed and stating the reasons therefor, or (2) does not respond to a request for a �51�modification or rescission in accordance with paragraph (b) of this section or (3) notifies the petitioner in writing that the matter is under continuing consideration and that no decision can be made at that time because of the inadequacy of available information, changing circumstances or other reasons as set forth therein, within 45 days of the date of the receipt thereof, or within such extended time as the Director may prescribe by written notice within that 45-day period, the request shall be considered denied for the purpose of review of such denial under �1A2901.7. 

I80�1A2901.6
I89Exceptions and exemptions.
I11(a) T3Request for exception or exemption.G1T1 (1) Any person seeking an exception or exemption from the Essential Agricultural Uses and Requirements regulations in part 2900 shall file a formal written request with the Director. The request shall contain a full and complete statement of all relevant facts pertaining to the circumstance, act, or transaction that is the subject of the request and to the action sought. The request should state the special hardship, inequity or unfair distribution of burdens that will be prevented by making the exception or exemption. The Director shall publish a notice in the T4Federal RegisterG1T1 advising the public that a request for an exception or exemption has been received and that written comments will be accepted with respect thereto if received within 20 days of the notice. The T4Federal RegisterG1T1 notice will provide that copies of the request from which confidential information has been deleted in accordance with paragraph (a)(2) of this section may be obtained from the petitioner. The Petitioner shall be afforded an opportunity to respond to such submissions.
I11(2) If the petitioner wishes to claim confidential treatment for any information contained in the request or other documents submitted under this part 2901, such person shall file together with the document a second copy of the document from which has been deleted the information for which such person wishes to claim confidential treatment. The petitioner shall indicate in the original document that it is confidential or contains confidential information and may file a statement specifying the justification for non-disclosure of the information for which non-disclosure is sought. The Director shall consider such requests, and subject to the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. 552 and other applicable laws and regulations, shall treat such information as confidential.
I11(b) T3Decision and order.G1T1 Upon consideration of the request for an exception or exemption and other relevant information received or obtained during the proceedings, the Director shall issue an order granting or denying the request. The Director shall publish a notice in the T4Federal RegisterG1T1 of the issuance of a decision and order on the request. The granting of a request for an exception or exemption shall be considered final agency action for purposes of judicial review under �1A2901.8.
I11(c) T3Denial of an exception or exemption.G1T1 A request for an exception or exemption shall be considered denied for purposes of review of such denial under �1A2901.7 only if: 
I11(1) The Director has notified the petitioner in writing that the request is denied under paragraph (b) of this section; or
I11(2) The Director does not respond to a request for an exception or exemption by (i) granting the request for an exception or exemption under paragraph (b) of this section or (ii) giving notice of when a decision will be made within 45 days of the receipt of the request, or with such extended time as the Director may prescribe by written notice within the 45-day period.

I80�1A2901.7
I89Review of denials.
I11(a) T3Request for review.G1T1 (1) Any person aggrieved or adversely affected by a denial of a request for any interpretation under �1A2901.4 may request a review of the denial by the Secretary, within 30 days from the date of the denial.
I11(2) Any person aggrieved or adversely affected by a denial of a request for a modification or rescission under �1A2901.5, may request a review of the denial by the Secretary within 30 days from the date of the denial.
I11(3) Any person aggrieved or adversely affected by a denial of a request for an exception or an exemption under �52��1A2901.6, may request a review of the denial by the Secretary within 30 days from the date of the denial. 
I11(b) T3Procedures.G1T1 Any request for review under �1A2901.7(a) shall be in writing and shall set forth the specific ground upon which the request is based. There is no final agency action for purposes of judicial review under �1A2901.8 until that request has been acted upon. If the request for review has not been acted upon within 30 days after it is received, the request shall be deemed to have been denied. That denial shall then constitute final agency action for the purpose of judicial review under �1A2901.8.

I80�1A2901.8
I89Judicial review.
I11Any person aggrieved or adversely affected by a final agency action taken on a request for an adjustment under this section may obtain judicial review in accordance with section 506 of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978.

I80�1A2901.9
I89Effective date.
I11This rule shall become effective on October 29, 1979.

�55�I52PART 3011_AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I263011.1General statement.
I263011.2Public inspection and copying.
I263011.3Indexes.
I263011.4Initial requests for records.
I263011.5Appeals.
I263011.6Fee schedule.

Q04I21T5Authority:  T15 U.S.C. 301 and 522; 7 CFR 1.3.
Q04I21T5Source:  T154 FR 51869, Dec. 19, 1989, unless otherwise noted.

I80�1A3011.1 
I89General statement.
I11This part is issued in accordance with 7 CFR 1.3 of the Department of Agriculture regulations governing the availability of records (7 CFR 1.1_1.23 and Appendix A) under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. 552, as amended). These regulations supplement the Department's regulations by providing guidance for any person wishing to request records from the Office of Finance and Management (OFM).

I80�1A3011.2 
I89Public inspection and copying.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) requires each agency to maintain and make available for public inspection and copying certain kinds of records.
I11(b) T3Procedure.G1T1 To gain access to OFM records that are available for public inspection, contact the Freedom of Information Act Officer by writing to the address shown in �1A3011.4(b) of this title.


I80�1A3011.3
I89Indexes.
I115 U.S.C. 552(a)(2) also requires that each agency maintain and make available for public inspection and copying current indexes providing identifying information for the public with regard to any records which are made available for public inspection and copying. OFM does not maintain any materials within the scope of these requirements.

I80�1A3011.4
I89Initial requests for records.
I11(a) T3Background.G1T1 The Freedom of Information Act Officer is authorized to: 
I11(1) Grant or deny requests for OFM records,
I11(2) Make discretionary release of OFM records when the benefit to the public in releasing the document outweighs any harm likely to result from disclosure,
I11(3) Reduce or waive fees to be charged where determined to be appropriate.
I11(b) T3Procedures.G1T1 This part provides the titles and mailing address of officials who are authorized to release records to the public. The normal working hours of these offices are 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., local time, Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, during which public inspection and copying of certain kinds of records is permitted. Persons wishing to request records from the Office of Finance and Management may do so by submitting each initial written request for OFM records to the appropriate OFM official shown below:
I11(1) For records held at the Washington, DC Headquarters units, submit initial requests to the Freedom of Information Act Officer, Office of Finance and Management, USDA, 14th and Independence Ave., SW., Room 117�09W, Administration Building, Washington, DC 20250�099000.
I11(2) For records held at the National Finance Center in New Orleans, Louisiana, submit initial requests to the Freedom of Information Act Officer, National Finance Center, OFM, USDA, 13800 Old Gentilly Road, Building 350, (P.O. Box 60,000, New Orleans, LA 70160), New Orleans, Louisiana 70129.
Q02I10If the requester is unable to determine the official to whom the request should be addressed, it should be submitted to the Headquarters Freedom of Information Act Officer who will refer such requests to the appropriate officials.

I80�1A3011.5
I89Appeals.
I11Any person whose initial request is denied in whole or in part may appeal that denial, in accordance with 7 CFR 1.6(e) and 1.8, to the Director, Office of Finance and Management, USDA, Room 117�09W, Administration Building, 14th and Independence Ave., Washington, DC 20250�099000.

I80�1A3011.6
I89Fee schedule.
I11Departmental regulations provide for a schedule of reasonable standard charges for document search and duplication. See 7 CFR 1.2(b). Fees to be charged are set forth in 7 CFR part 1, subpart A, Appendix A.

I86Subpart E_Waiver of ``Single'' State Agency Requirements 
I263015.30Waiver of ``single'' State agency requirements. 

I86Subpart F_Grant Related Income 
I263015.40Scope. 
I263015.41General program income.
