I263100.46Responsibilities of the Department of Agriculture. 
S8006I56Subparts A�09B [Reserved]
S8010
I56Subpart C_Enhancement, Protection, and Management of the Cultural Environment
Q04I21T5Authority:  T1Sec. 106, National Historic Preservation Act, as amended (16 U.S.C. 470f); National Environmental Policy Act, as amended (42 U.S.C. 4321 T3et seq.G1T1); E.O. 11593, 36 FR 8921, May 13, 1971.
Q04I21T5Source:  T144 FR 66181, Nov. 19, 1979, unless otherwise noted. 

I80�1A3100.40
I89Purpose.
I11(a) This subpart establishes USDA policy regarding the enhancement, protection, and management of the cultural environment.
I11(b) This subpart establishes procedures for implementing Executive Order 11593, and regulations promulgated by the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation (ACHP) ``Protection of Historical and Cultural Properties'' in 36 CFR part 800 as required by �1A800.10 of those regulations.
I11(c) Direction is provided to the agencies of USDA for protection of the cultural environment.

I80�1A3100.41
I89Authorities.
I11These regulations are based upon and implement the following laws, regulations, and Presidential directives:
I11(a) T3Antiquities Act of 1906G1T1 (Pub. L. 59�09209; 34 Stat. 225; 16 U.S.C. 431 T3et seq.G1T1) which provides for the protection of historic or prehistoric remains or any object of antiquity on Federal lands; establishes criminal sanctions for unauthorized destruction or appropriation of antiquities; and authorizes scientific investigation of antiquities on Federal lands, subject to permit and regulations. Paleontological resources also are considered to fall within the authority of this Act.
I11(b) T3Historic Sites Act of 1935G1T1 (Pub. L. 74�09292; 49 Stat. 666; 16 U.S.C. 461 T3et seq.G1T1) which authorizes the establishment of National Historic Sites and otherwise authorizes the preservation of properties of national historical or archeological significance; authorizes the designation of National Historic Landmarks; establishes criminal sanctions for violation of regulations pursuant to the Act; authorizes interagency, intergovernmental, and interdisciplinary efforts for the preservation of cultural resources; and other provisions.
I11(c) T3Reservoir Salvage Act of 1960G1T1 (Pub. L. 86�09521; 74 Stat. 220; 16 U.S.C. 469�09469c.) which provides for the recovery and preservation of historical and archeological data, including relics and specimens, that might be lost or destroyed as a result of the construction of dams, reservoirs, and attendant facilities and activities.
I11(d) T3The National Historic Preservation Act of 1966G1T1 as amended (16 U.S.C. 470), which establishes positive national policy for the preservation of the cultural environment, and sets forth a mandate for protection in section 106. The purpose of section 106 is to protect properties on or eligible for the National Register of Historic Places through review and comment by the ACHP of Federal undertakings that affect such properties. Properties are listed on the National Register or declared eligible for listing by the Secretary of the Interior. As developed through the ACHP's regulations, section 106 establishes a public interest process in which the Federal agency proposing an undertaking, the State Historic Preservation Officer, the ACHP, interested organizations and individuals participate. The process is designed to insure that properties, impacts on them, and effects to them are identified, and that alternatives to avoid or mitigate an adverse effect on property eligible for the National Register are adequately considered in the planning process.
I11(e) T3The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969G1T1 (NEPA) (Pub. L. 91�09190; 83 �220�Stat. 852; 42 U.S.C. 4321 T3et seq.G1T1) which declares that it is the policy of the Federal Government to preserve important historic, cultural, and natural aspects of our national heritage. Compliance with NEPA requires consideration of all environmental concerns during project planning and execution.
I11(f) T3Executive Order 11593, ``Protection and Enhancement of the Cultural Environment'',G1T1 which gives the Federal Government the responsibility for stewardship of our nation's heritage resources and charges Federal agencies with the task of inventorying historic and prehistoric sites on their lands. E.O. 11593 also charges agencies with the task of identifying and nominating all historic properties under their jurisdiction, and exercising caution to insure that they are not transferred, sold, demolished, or substantially altered.
I11(g) T3Historical and Archeological Data Preservation Act of 1974.G1T1 (Pub. L. 93�09291; 88 Stat. 174.) which amends the Reservoir Salvage Act of 1960 to extend its provisions beyond the construction of dams to any alteration of the terrain caused as a result of any Federal construction project or federally licensed activity or program. In addition, the Act provides a mechanism for funding the protection of historical and archeological data.
I11(h) T3Presidential memorandum of July 12, 1978, ``Environmental Quality and Water Resource Management''G1T1 which directs the ACHP to publish final regulations, implementing section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act (NHPA), and further directs each agency with water and related land resources responsibilities to publish procedures implementing those regulations.
I11(i) T336 CFR part 800,G1T1 ``Protection of Historic and Cultural Properties'' which establishes procedures for the implementation of section 106 of the NHPA, and directs publication of agency implementing procedures.
I11(j) T3Land use policy of the USDA (Secretary's Memorandum No. 1827 Revised, with Supplement)G1T1 which establishes a commitment by the Department to the preservation of farms, rural communities, and rural landscapes.
I11(k) T3Public Buildings Cooperative Use Act of 1976 (40 U.S.C. 611) and Executive Order 12072 (Federal Space Management).G1T1 The Act encourages adaptive use of historic buildings as administrative facilities for Federal agencies and activities; the Executive Order directs Federal agencies to locate administrative and other facilities in central business districts.
I11(l) T3American Indian Religious Freedom Act of 1978 (42 U.S.C. 1996)G1T1 which declares it to be the policy of the United States to protect and preserve for American Indians their inherent right of freedom to believe, express, and exercise the traditional religions of the American Indian, Eskimo, Aleut, and Native Hawaiians.

I80�1A3100.42
I89Definitions.
I11All definitions are those which appear in 36 CFR part 800. In addition, the following apply in this rule:
I11T3Cultural resources (heritage resources)G1T1 are the remains or records of districts, sites, structures, buildings, networks, neighborhoods, objects, and events from the past. They may be historic, prehistoric, archeological, or architectural in nature. Cultural resources are an irreplaceable and nonrenewable aspect of our national heritage.
I11T3Cultural environmentG1T1 is that portion of the environment which includes reminders of the rich historic and prehistoric past of our nation.

I80�1A3100.43
I89Policy.
I11(a) The nonrenewable cultural environment of our country constitutes a valuable and treasured portion of the national heritage of the American people. The Department of Agriculture is committed to the management_identification, protection, preservation, interpretation, evaluation and nomination_of our prehistoric and historic cultural resources for the benefit of all people of this and future generations.
I11(b) The Department supports the cultural resource goals expressed in Federal legislation. Executive orders, and regulations.
I11(c) The Department supports the preservation and protection of farms, rural landscapes, and rural communities.
I11(d) The Department is committed to consideration of the needs of American �221�Indians, Eskimo, Aleut, and Native Hawaiians in the practice of their traditional religions. 
I11(e) The Department will aggressively implement these policies to meet goals for the positive management of the cultural environment.

I80�1A3100.44
I89Implementation.
I11(a) It is the intent of the Department to carry out its program of management of the cultural environment in the most effective and efficient manner possible. Implementation must consider natural resource utilization, must exemplify good government, and must constitute a noninflationary approach which makes the best use of tax dollars.
I11(b) The commitment to cultural resource protection is vital. That commitment will be balanced with the multiple departmental goals of food and fiber production, environmental protection, natural resource and energy conservation, and rural development. It is essential that all of these be managed to reduce conflicts between programs. Positive management of the cultural environment can contribute to achieving better land use, protection of rural communities and farm lands, conservation of energy, and more efficient use of resources.
I11(c) In reaching decisions, the long-term needs of society and the irreversible nature of an action must be considered. The Department must act to preserve future options; loss of important cultural resources must be avoided except in the face of overriding national interest where there are no reasonable alternatives.
I11(d) To assure the protection of Native American religious practices, traditional religious leaders and other native leaders (or their representatives) should be consulted about potential conflict areas in the management of the cultural environment and the means to reduce or eliminate such conflicts.

I80�1A3100.45
I89Direction to agencies.
I11(a) Each agency of the Department shall consult with OEQ to determine whether its programs and activities may affect the cultural environment. Then, if needed, the agency, in consultation with the OEQ, shall develop its own specific procedures for implementing section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act, Executive Order 11593, the regulations of the ACHP (36 CFR part 800), the American Indian Religious Freedom Act of 1978 and other relevant legislation and regulations in accordance with the agency's programs, mission and authorities. Such implementing procedures shall be published as proposed and final procedures in the T4Federal Register,G1T1 and must be consistent with the requirements of 36 CFR part 800 and this subpart. Where applicable, each agency's procedures must contain mechanisms to insure:
I11(1) Compliance with section 106 of NHPA and mitigation of adverse effects to cultural properties on or eligible for the National Register of Historic Places;
I11(2) Clear definition of the kind and variety of sites and properties which should be managed;
I11(3) Development of a long-term program of management of the cultural environment on lands administered by USDA as well as direction for project-specific protection;
I11(4) Identification of all properties listed on or eligible for listing in the National Register that may be affected directly or indirectly by a proposed activity;
I11(5) Location, identification and nomination to the Register of all sites, buildings, objects, districts, neighborhoods, and networks under its management which appear to qualify (in compliance with E.O. 11593);
I11(6) The exercise of caution to assure that properties managed by USDA which may qualify for nomination are not transferred, sold, demolished, or substantially altered;
I11(7) Early consultation with, and involvement of, the State Historic Preservation Officer(s), the ACHP, Native American traditional religious leaders and appropriate tribal leaders, and others with appropriate interests or expertise;
I11(8) Early notification to insure substantive and meaningful involvement by the public in the agency's decisionmaking process as it relates to the cultural environment;
�222�I11(9) Identification and consideration of alternatives to a proposed undertaking that would mitigate or minimize adverse effects to a property identified under paragraph (a)(4) of this section;
I11(10) Funding of mitigation measures where required to minimize the potential for adverse effects on the cultural environment. Funds for mitigation shall be available and shall be spent when needed during the life of the project to mitigate the expected loss; and
I11(11) Development of plans to provide for the management, protection, maintenance and/or restoration of Register sites under its management.
I11(b) Each agency of the Department which conducts programs or activities that may have an effect on the cultural environment shall recruit, place, develop, or otherwise have available, professional expertise in anthropology, archeology, history, historic preservation, historic architecture, and/or cultural resource management (depending upon specific need). Such arrangements may include internal hiring, Intergovernmental Personnel Act assignments, memoranda of agreement with other agencies or Departments, or other mechanisms which insure a professionally directed program. Agencies should use Department of the Interior professional standards (36 CFR 61.5) as guidelines to insure Departmentwide competence and consistency.
I11(c) Compliance with cultural resource legislation is the responsibility of each individual agency. Consideration of cultural resource values must begin during the earliest planning stages of any undertaking. 
I11(d) Agency heads shall insure that cultural resource management activities meet professional standards as promulgated by the Department of the Interior (e.g., 36 CFR parts 60, 63, 66, 1208). 
I11(e) Cultural resource review requirements and compliance with section 106 of NHPA and Executive Order 11593 shall be integrated and run concurrently, rather than consecutively, with the other environmental considerations under NEPA regulations. As such, direct and indirect impacts on cultural resources must be addressed in the environmental assessment for every agency undertaking. In meeting these requirements, agencies shall be guided by regulations implementing the procedural provisions of NEPA (40 CFR parts 1500�091508) and Department of Agriculture regulations (7 CFR part 3100, subpart B). 
I11(f) Each agency shall work closely with the appropriate State Historic Preservation Officer(s) in their preparation of State plans, determination of inventory needs, and collection of data relevant to general plans or specific undertakings in carrying out mutual cultural resource responsibilities. 
I11(g) Each agency shall, to the maximum extent possible, use existing historic structures for administrative purposes in compliance with Public Buildings Cooperative Use Act of 1976 and Executive Order 12072, ``Federal Space Management''. 
I11(h) Each agency should consult with Native American traditional religious leaders or their representatives and other native leaders in the development and implementation of cultural resource programs which may affect their religious customs and practices. 

I80�1A3100.46 
I89Responsibilities of the Department of Agriculture. 
I11(a) Within the Department, the responsibility for the protection of the cultural environment is assigned to the Office of Environmental Quality (OEQ). The Office is responsible for reviewing the development and implementation of agency procedures and insuring Departmental commitment to cultural resource goals. 
I11(b) The Director of the OEQ is the Secretary's Designee to the ACHP. 
I11(c) In order to carry out cultural resource responsibilities, there will be professional expertise within the OEQ to advise agencies, aid the Department in meeting its cultural resource management goals, and to insure that all Departmental and agency undertakings comply with applicable cultural resource protection legislation and regulations. 
I11(d) The OEQ will be involved in individual compliance cases only where resolution cannot be reached at the agency level. Prior to the decision to refer a matter to the full Council of the �223�ACHP, the OEQ will review the case and make recommendations to the Secretary regarding the position of the Department. The agency also will consult with the OEQ before reaching a final decision in response to the Council's comments. Copies of correspondence relevant to compliance with Section 106 shall be made available to OEQ.

I52PART 3200_DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE GUIDELINES FOR THE ACQUISITION AND TRANSFER OF EXCESS PERSONAL PROPERTY
S8006I18Sec.
S8010I263200.1Purpose.
I263200.2Eligibility.
I263200.3Definitions.
I263200.4Procedures.
I263200.5Dollar limitation.
I263200.6Restrictions.
I263200.7Title.

Q04I21T5Authority: T15 U.S.C. 301; 7 U.S.C. 2206a.

Q04I21T5Source: T163 FR 57234, Oct. 27, 1998, unless otherwise noted.




I80�1A3200.1
I89Purpose.
I11This Part sets forth the procedures to be utilized by Department of Agriculture (USDA) in the acquisition and transfer of excess property to the 1890 Land Grant Institutions (including Tuskegee University), 1994 Land Grant Institutions, and the Hispanic-Serving Institutions in support of research, educational, technical, and scientific activities or for related programs as authorized by 7 U.S.C. 2206a. Title to the personal property shall pass to the institution.


I80�1A3200.2
I89Eligibility.
I11Institutions that are eligible to receive Federal excess personal property pursuant to the provisions of this part are the 1890 Land Grant Institutions (including Tuskegee University), 1994 Land Grant Institutions, and the Hispanic-Serving Institutions conducting research, educational, technical, and scientific activities or related programs.


I80�1A3200.3
I89Definitions.
I11(a) T31890 Land grant institutionsG1T1_any college or university eligible to receive funds under the Act of August 30, 1890 (7 U.S.C. 321 et.seq.), including Tuskegee University.
I11(b) T31994 Land grant institutionsG1T1_any of the tribal colleges or universities as defined in section 532 of the Equity in Educational Land-Grant Status Act of 1994 (7 U.S.C. 301 note).
I11(c) T3Hispanic-serving institutionsG1T1_institutions of higher education as defined in section 316(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1059c (b)).
I11(d) T3Property management officerG1T1_is an authorized USDA or institution official responsible for property management.
I11(e) T3ScreenerG1T1_is an individual designated by an eligible institution and authorized by the General Services Administration (GSA) to visit property sites for the purpose of inspecting personal property intended for use by the institution.
I11(f) T3Excess personal propertyG1T1_is any personal property under the control of a Federal agency that is no longer needed.
I11(g) T3CannibalizationG1T1_is the dismantling of equipment for parts to repair or enhance other equipment.


I80�1A3200.4
I89Procedures.
I11(a) To receive information concerning the availability of Federal excess personal property, an eligible institution's property management officer may contact their regional GSA, Area Utilization Officer. All property management officers of eligible institutions will be placed on the USDA mailing list for information on the availability of property. USDA excess property will first be screened by USDA agencies through the Departmental Excess Personal Property Coordinator (DEPPC) using the PMIS/PROP system.
I11(b) Excess property selected by screeners of eligible institutions should be inspected whenever possible, or the holding agency should be contacted to verify the condition of the items, because interpretation of condition codes varies among Federal agencies.
I11(c) If the condition of the item is acceptable, the institution should ``freeze'' (reserve) items by calling the appropriate GSA office or USDA Departmental Excess Personal Property Coordinator (DEPPC). Since GSA may have several ``freezes'' on a piece of equipment, it is critical that the paperwork be submitted as soon as possible. Further, while transfers of excess personal property normally will be approved by GSA on a first-come-first-serve basis, consideration will be given �228�to such factors as national defense requirements, emergency needs, preclusion of new procurement, energy conservation, equitable distribution, and retention of title in the Government.
I11(d) Eligible institutions may submit property requests by mail or fax on a Standard Form 122, ``Transfer Order Excess Personal Property,'' with a written justification statement (submitted by the recipient) explaining how the property will be used for research, educational, technical, or scientific activity or for related programs.
I11(e) The SF�09122 should be signed by the eligible institution's property management officer or authorized designee.
I11(1) The following information should also be provided:
I11(i) Date prepared.
I11(ii) GSA/DEPPC address.
I11(iii) Ordering Agency and address.
I11(iv) Holding Agency and address.
I11(v) Name and address of Institution.
I11(vi) Location of property.
I11(vii) Shipping instruction (including institution contact person and phone number).
I11(viii) Complete description of property including original acquisition cost, serial number, condition code, and quantity.


I11(2) This statement needs to be added following the property description but does not serve as a justification statement:

Q04



I21The property requested hereon is certified to be used in support of research, educational, technical, and scientific activities or for related programs. This transfer is requested pursuant to the provisions of section 923 of Pub. L. 104�09127 (7 U.S.C. 2206a).

Q04

I11(f) The SF�09122 should be forwarded to USDA for approval and signature by an authorized USDA official. As confirmation of approval, the eligible institution's property management officer will receive a stamped copy of the SF�09122. If the request is disapproved, it will be returned to the property management officer of the eligible institution with an appropriate explanation. All USDA approved SF�09122's will be forwarded to DEPPC or the appropriate GSA office for final approval.
I11(g) Once the excess personal property is physically received, the institution is required to immediately return a copy of the SF�09122 to USDA indicating receipt of requested items. Cancellations should also be reported to USDA.

Q04

I21T5Note: T1USDA shall send an informational copy of all SF�09122's transactions to GSA.


I80�1A3200.5
I89Dollar limitation.
I11There is no dollar limitation on excess personal property obtained under these procedures.


I80�1A3200.6
I89Restrictions.
I11(a) The authorized USDA official will approve the transfer of excess personal property in the following groups for the 1890 Land Grant Institutions (including Tuskegee University), 1994 Land Grant Institutions and the Hispanic-Serving Institutions in support of research, educational, technical, and scientific activities or for related programs:

I21T5Note to paragraph T1(a): Requests for items in Federal Supply Code Groups other than those listed in this paragraph shall be referred to the Director of OPPM for consideration and approval.

I11(b) Excess personal property may be transferred for the purpose of cannibalization, provided the eligible institution submits a supporting statement which clearly indicates that cannibalizing the requested property for secondary use has greater benefit than utilization of the item in its existing form.
I11(c) Use of the procedures in this part for the purpose of stockpiling of excess personal property for future cannibalization is prohibited. Transfer requests for the purpose of cannibalization will be considered, but are normally subordinate to requests for complete items.


I80�1A3200.7
I89Title.
I11Title to excess personal property obtained under Part 3200 will automatically pass to the 1890 Land Grant Institutions (including Tuskegee University), 1994 Land Grant Institutions, and the Hispanic-Serving Institutions once USDA receives the SF�09122 indicating that the institution has received the property. Note: When competing Federal claims are made for particular items of excess personal property held by agencies other than USDA, with or without payment of reimbursement, GSA will give preference to the Federal agency that will retain title in the Government.


I80�1A3200.8
I89Costs.
I11Excess personal property obtained under this part is provided free of charge. However, the institution must pay all costs associated with packaging and transportation. The institution should specify the method of shipment on the SF�09122.


I80�1A3200.9
I89Accountability and record keeping.
I11USDA requires that Federal excess personal property received by an eligible institution pursuant to this part shall be placed into use for a research, educational, technical, or scientific activity, or for a related purpose, within 1 year of receipt of the property, and used for such purpose for at least 1 year thereafter. The institution's property management officer must establish and maintain accountable records identifying the property's location, description, utilization and value. To ensure that the excess personal property is being used for its intended purpose under this part, compliance reviews will be conducted by an authorized representative of USDA. The review will include site visit inspections of the property and the accountability and record keeping systems.


�230�I80�1A3200.10
I89Disposal.
I11When the property is no longer needed by the institution, it may be used in support of other Federal projects or sold, and the proceeds used for research, educational, technical, and scientific activities, or for related programs of the recipient institution.


I80�1A3200.11
I89Liabilities and losses.
I11USDA assumes no liability with respect to accidents, bodily injury, illness, or any other damages or loss related to excess personal property transferred under this part.

Q04I21T5Authority:  T1Sec. 4, Pub. L. 97�09325, International Carriage of Perishable Foodstuffs Act (7 U.S.C. 4403). 
Q04I21T5Source:  T151 FR 33879, Sept. 24, 1986, unless otherwise noted.

I56Subpart A_Introduction 

I80�1A3300.1
I89Scope of authority and purpose. 
I11The International Carriage of Perishable Foodstuffs Act assigns to the Secretary of Agriculture the responsibility for implementation of the Agreement on the International Carriage of Perishable Foodstuffs and on the Special Equipment to be Used for Such Carriage (ATP). The purpose of this rule is to establish procedures for the inspection, testing, and certification of insulated, refrigerated, mechanically refrigerated, and heated transport equipment in accordance with the Act and the standards specified in the Agreement. In the process, the intent is to utilize existing industry organizations and facilities for testing and inspection of equipment. The Secretary is the sole authority to issue certificates of compliance. 

I80�1A3300.4
I89Definitions. 
I11T3AdministratorG1T1 means the Administrator, Office of Transportation, U.S. Department of Agriculture, whose address is: 1405 Auditors Building, 201 14th Street, SW., Washington, DC 20250. 
�234�I11T3ATPG1T1 means the Agreement on the International Carriage of Perishable Foodstuffs and on the Special Equipment to be Used for Such Carriage (ATP), and the annexes and appendices thereto, done at Geneva, September 1, 1970, under the auspices of the Economic Commission for Europe, and any subsequent amendments thereto.\1\N 

I28N\1\�1AA copy of the agreement can be obtained by request to the ATP Manager, Office of Transportation, U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1405 Auditors Building, 201 14th Street, SW., Washington, DC 20250. 

I11T3ATP managerG1T1 means the person designated by the Administrator to manage the program established by this rule, whose address is: ATP Manager, Office of Transportation, U.S Department of Agriculture, 1405 Auditors Building, 201 14th Street, SW., Washington, DC 20250. 
I11T3Contracting partyG1T1 means a country which is signatory to the ATP. 
I11T3Domestic ownerG1T1 means an organization incorporated or chartered under the laws of, and with principal office in, the United States, and to which one of the following applies: 
I11(a) The organization owns and operates the equipment directly. 
I11(b) The organization owns and operates the equipment through a wholly owned subsidiary in a foreign country. 
I11(c) The organization is a lessee or bailee of the equipment, and a written lease or bailment provides that the organization is responsible for any inspection, testing, and certification of the equipment with respect to the ATP rule. 
I11T3EquipmentG1T1 means the special transport equipment that meets the definitions and standards set forth in ATP, Annex 1, including, but not limited to, railcars, trucks, trailers, semitrailers, and intermodal freight containers that have an insulated body only, or an insulated body equipped with a refrigerating, mechanically refrigerating, or heating appliance. 
I11T3Equipment manufacturerG1T1 means an organization which producers or assembles the complete unit of equipment, that is, the insulated body with the thermal appliance installed. 
I11T3Foreign ownerG1T1 means an organization registered under the laws of, or with principal office in, a country outside the United States, and which owns or operates the equipment. 
I11T3Foreign-ATP certificateG1T1 means a certificate issued by a foreign country which is a contracting party to the ATP, attesting that the equipment listed in the certificate complies with pertinent standards in the ATP. 
I11T3Identical mechanical refrigerating applianceG1T1 means an appliance which is of the same model number and design as the reference mechanical refrigerating appliance. 
I11T3Insulated bodyG1T1 means the six-sided structural component of equipment, consisting of insulated doors, sidewalls, roof, floor, and endwall, inside which perishable foodstuffs are carried. 
I11T3International carriageG1T1 means transportation of perishable foodstuffs if such foodstuffs are loaded in equipment or the equipment containing them is loaded onto a rail or road vehicle, in the territory of any country and such foodstuffs are, or the equipment containing them is, unloaded in the territory of another country that is a contracting party, where such transportation is by: 
I11(a) Rail, 
I11(b) Road, 
I11(c) Any combination of rail and road, or 
I11(d) Any sea crossing of less than one hundred and fifty kilometers, if preceded or followed by one or more land journeys as referred to in clauses (a), (b), and (c) of this definition, and the perishable foodstuffs are shipped in the same equipment used for such land journeys without transloading of such foodstuffs. 
Q02I10In the case of any transportation that involves one or more sea crossings other than as specified in clause (d) of this definition, each land journey shall be considered separately. 
I11T3New equipmentG1T1 means equipment produced or assembled on or after the effective date of this rule. 
I11T3Perishable foodstuffsG1T1 means the quick deep-frozen and frozen food products listed in Annex 2, and the chilled food products listed in Annex 3 to the ATP. 
I11T3Reference equipmentG1T1 means a unit of equipment which has passed a test in an approved testing station, and can thereby serve as a basis for certification of related serially-produced equipment. 
�235�I11T3Reference insulated bodyG1T1 means an insulated body which has passed a test in an approved testing station for measurement of the K-coefficient of the body, and can thereby serve as the basis for approval of serially-produced bodies in the case in which the body and the mechanical refrigerating appliance of the equipment are tested separately. 
I11T3Reference mechanical refrigerating applianceG1T1 means an appliance which has passed a test in an approved testing laboratory, and can thereby serve as the basis for approval of identical mechanical refrigerating appliances in the case in which the appliance and the insulated body of the equipment are tested separately. 
I11T3Serially-produced bodiesG1T1 means insulated bodies which meet the definition in ATP, Annex 1 Appendix 1, paragraph 2(c)(i). 
I11T3Serially-produced equipmentG1T1 means equipment of a specific type (container, semi-trailer, trailer, truck, or container), which meets the definition in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 2(c), (i), (ii), (iii), and (iv). 
I11T3Thermal applianceG1T1 means the refrigerating, mechanical refrigerating, or heating appliance which is installed in the insulated body of the equipment. 
I11T3United StatesG1T1 means the fifty States of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands of the United States, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and any other territory or possession of the United States. 
I11T3U.S. ATP certificateG1T1 means a certificate issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, attesting that the equipment listed in the certificate complies with pertinent standards in the ATP.
I11T3U.S. ATP testing laboratoryG1T1 means a facility in the United States which has been approved by the Administrator to conduct tests of mechanical refrigerating appliances. 
I11T3U.S. ATP testing stationG1T1 means a facility in the United States which has been approved by the Administrator to conduct tests of equipment. 

I56Subpart B_Procedures for Testing of Equipment 

I80�1A3300.7 
I89General. 
I11Testing of equipment according to the ATP is basically done in two phases: 
I11(a) Measurement of the insulating capacity, that is, the K-coefficient, of the insulated body. 
I11(b) Determination of the efficiency of the thermal appliance as installed in the insulated body. In the case of mechanically refrigerated equipment, the mechanical refrigerating appliance may be tested separate from the body. 

I80�1A3300.10 
I89Measurement of the K-coefficient of an insulated body. 
I11The K-coefficient shall be measured according to the procedures in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2, paragraphs 1�0928, and the following shall apply:
I11(a) The internal heating method shall be used. 
I11(b) In ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2, paragraph 8, last line, ``about +20 G6T1�G1T1C for the mean temperature of the walls of the body shall be interpreted to mean between +19 G6T1�G1T1C (+66 G6T1�G1T1F) and 21 G6T1�G1T1C (+70 G6T1�G1T1F).
I11(c) A report of each test shall be completed on a form corresponding to the pertinent test report model prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2. Report forms may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. 

I80�1A3300.13 
I89Determination of the efficiency of the thermal appliances as installed in the insulated body. 
I11In determining the efficiency of a thermal appliance with respect to maintaining a prescribed temperature inside the body, the procedures in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2, paragraphs 31�0940 and 43�0947 shall be used. A report of each test shall be completed on a form corresponding to the pertinent test report model prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2. Report forms may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager.

�236�I56Subpart C_Approval of Testing Stations 

I80�1A3300.16 
I89General. 
I11Any public or private organization incorporated or chartered under the laws of, and with principal office in, the United States may apply to have one or more of its facilities in the United States designated as a U.S. ATP testing station. 

I80�1A3300.19 
I89Application for approval. 
I11An application by an officer of the organization shall be submitted to the Administrator for each facility for which approval is sought. Copies of the Form, Application for Approval as a U.S. ATP Testing Station, may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. The following information must be supplied in the application: 
I11(a) A statement that the organization is incorporated or chartered under the laws of, and that it has its principal office in, the United States, including the name, address, and telephone number of the principal office. 
I11(b) The address and telephone number of the testing station, and name and title of person in charge of the station. 
I11(c) A summary of experience at the facility which would indicate the capability to conduct tests of equipment according to Supart B of this rule. 
I11(d) A general description of the station, including drawings on letter size (8 \1/2\ �0A 11 inches) paper to show the floor plan and cross-sections of the test chamber, basic dimensions, location of heat exchangers and instruments, and any other pertinent information. 
I11(e) An indication of which of the following types of equipment, as defined in ATP, Annex 1, that the station is capable of testing: intermodal freight containers, semi-trailers, trailers, railcars, and trucks. 
I11(f) A statement that the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator may, before a decision is made concerning the application, observe a test at the station of a Class ``C'' mechanically refrigerated container or semi-trailer, with Class ``C'' being defined as in ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3.
I11(g) A statement that the station will be open to public use, that is, to manufacturers and owners of equipment which may apply to have equipment tested. 
I11(h) A statement that the fees to be charged by the organization for testing will be reasonable with respect to costs involved, and that such fees will be payable directly to the organization by those who seek testing of their equipment. 
I11(i) A statement that the station will maintain records of basic data developed in each test conducted under this rule, such records to be available for review by the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator upon request. The record for each test shall be maintained for a period of three years.
I11(j) A statement that the organization will advise the ATP manager as soon as practicable of its intent to conduct a test under this rule and that it will, as soon as possible, advise when a firm test date has been set so that the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator may observe the test. 
I11(k) A statement that the organization will send to the ATP manager a copy of each test report for equipment tested at the station according to this rule, within 30 days after completion of the test. 
I11(l) A statement that, should any significant change occur in the facility with respect to structure or test equipment as a result of redesign or other cause during the period of approval, the organization will so advise the ATP manager within 30 days after such change. 
I11(m) Any other pertinent information. 

I80�1A3300.22 
I89Response to application for approval.
I11The Administrator will, within 30 days of receipt of the application and any relevant information required, advise the applicant whether or not the facility is approved as a testing station. Approval is for a 5-year period. 

I80�1A3300.25 
I89Application for renewal of approval. 
I11If an organization wishes to have an approval renewed at the end of a 5-year �237�period, it shall submit a request for renewal to the Administrator 90 days before expiration of the existing approval. The request for renewal shall contain the same type of information as required in the original application, that is, the information called for in �1A3300.19 of subpart C. 

I80�1A3300.28 
I89Response to application for renewal of approval. 
I11The Administrator will, within 30 days of receipt of application and any relevant information required, advise the applicant whether or not approval is renewed. A renewal is good for 5 years. 

I80�1A3300.31 
I89Termination of approval. 
I11An approved testing station may at any time withdraw as an approved testing station by written notice to the Administrator. Similarly, the Administrator may suspend or terminate for cause the approved status of a testing station by written notice to the organization, setting forth the reasons for such action. Examples of causes for suspension or termination of approval of a testing station would be a change in equipment or operations at the station which would render the station incapable of performing tests according to the standards in the ATP, or noncompliance of the station with pertinent portions of this rule. 

I56Subpart D_Procedures for Separate Testing of Mechanical Refrigerating Appliances 

I80�1A3300.34 
I89General. 
I11ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2, paragraph 41, provides that approval of mechanically refrigerated equipment may be done on the basis of separate testing of the mechanical refrigerating appliance. 

I80�1A3300.37 
I89Testing of a mechanical refrigerating appliance.
I11For separate testing of a mechanical refrigerating appliance, the following shall pertain: 
I11(a) The calibrated-box method shall be used, as set forth in ARI Standard 1110, Standard for Mechanical Refrigeration Units, of the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute. 
I11(b) The appliance shall be rated according to the class, or classes, of service for which the appliance is intended, with classes being defined as in ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3. 
I11(c) A report of each test shall be completed on a form corresponding to the pertinent test report model prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2. Report forms may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. 

I56Subpart E_Approval of Testing Laboratories

I80�1A3300.40 
I89General. 
I11Any public or private organization incorporated or chartered under the laws of, and with principal office in, the United States may apply to have one or more of its facilities in the United States designated as a U.S. ATP testing laboratory.

I80�1A3300.43 
I89Application for approval. 
I11An application by an officer of the organization shall be submitted to the Administrator for each facility for which approval is sought. Copies of the Form, Application for Approval as a U.S. ATP Testing Laboratory, may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. The following information must be supplied in the application:
I11(a) A statement that the organization is incorporated or chartered under the laws of, and that it has its principal office in, the United States, including the address and telephone number of the principal office.
I11(b) The address and telephone number of the testing laboratory, and name and title of person in charge of the laboratory.
I11(c) A summary of the experience at the facility which would indicate a capability to conduct tests of mechanical refrigerating appliances according to subpart D of this rule.
I11(d) A general description of the laboratory, including drawings on letter size (8\1/2\ �0A 11 inches) paper to show the floor plan and cross-section of the test chamber, basic dimensions, location of heat exchangers and instruments, and any other pertinent information.
I11(e) A statement that the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator may, before a decision is �238�made concerning the application, observe a test at the laboratory of a mechanical refrigerating appliance for a Class ``C'' mechanically refrigerated container or trailer, with Class ``C'' as defined in ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3.
I11(f) A statement that the laboratory will maintain records of basic data developed in each test conducted under this rule, such records to be available for review by the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator, upon request. The record for each test shall be maintained for a period of three years.
I11(g) A statement that the organization will advise the ATP manager as soon as practicable of its intent to conduct a test under this rule and that it will, as soon as possible, advise when a firm test has been set so that the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator may observe the test.
I11(h) A statement that the organization will send to the ATP manager a copy of each test report for an appliance tested at the laboratory according to this rule, within 30 days after completion of the test.
I11(i) A statement that, should any significant change occur in the facility with respect to structure or test equipment as a result of redesign or other cause during the period of approval, the organization will so advise the ATP manager within 30 days after such change.
I11(j) Any other pertinent information.

I80�1A3300.46 
I89Response to application for approval.
I11The Administrator will, within 30 days of receipt of an application and any relevant information required, advise the applicant whether or not the facility is approved as a testing laboratory. Approval is for a 5-year period from date of approval.

I80�1A3300.49 
I89Application for renewal of approval.
I11If an organization wishes to have an approval renewed at the end of a 5-year period, it shall submit a request for renewal to the Administrator 90 days before expiration of the existing approval. The request for renewal shall contain the same type of information as required in the original application, that is, the information called for in �1A3300.43 of subpart E.

I80�1A3300.52 
I89Response to application for renewal of approval.
I11The Administrator will, within 30 days of receipt of application and any relevant information required, advise the applicant whether or not approval is renewed. A renewal extends the period of approval for 5 years.

I80�1A3300.55 
I89Termination of approval. 
I11An approved testing laboratory may at any time withdraw as an approved testing laboratory by written notice to the Administrator. Similarly, the Administrator may suspend or terminate for cause the approved status of a testing laboratory by written notice to the organization, setting forth the reasons for such action. Examples of causes for suspension or termination of approval would be a change in equipment or operations at the laboratory which would render it incapable of performing tests according to the standards in the ATP, or noncompliance of the laboratory with pertinent portions of this rule. 

I56Subpart F_Certification of New Equipment 

I80�1A3300.58 
I89General. 
I11The following shall apply for certification of new equipment: 
I11(a) Domestic owners are eligible to receive U.S. ATP certificates for equipment produced or assembled in the United States or in a foreign country. 
I11(b) Foreign owners are eligible to receive U.S. ATP certificates only for equipment produced or assembled in the United States. 
I11(c) For equipment manufactured (i.e., produced or assembled) in the United States: 
I11(1) When the complete unit of equipment is tested, the test shall be performed in a U.S. ATP testing station.
I11(2) When the mechanical refrigerating appliance and the insulated body are tested separately, such tests shall be performed in approved testing facilities in the United States or in test facilities located in, and approved by, a foreign country which is a Contracting Party. 
�239�I11(d) For equipment manufactured in a foreign country which is a Contracting Party, a domestic owner may receive a U.S. ATP certiticate in exchange for the Foreign-ATP certificate issued by the country of manufacture.
I11(e) For equipment manufactured in a foreign country which is not a Contracting Party, tests shall be performed in approved testing facilities in the United States or in facilities located in and approved by a foreign country which is a Contracting Party.
I11(f) In accordance with ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 2(a) and (d), the validity of a test report for a reference equipment shall expire at the end of a period of 3 years or at the end of the manufacture of 1,000 units of serially-produced equipment, whichever occurs first.
I11(g) The validity of a test report for a reference mechanical refrigerating appliance shall expire at the end of a period of three years, or at the end of the manufacture of 1,000 identical mechanical refrigerating appliances, whichever occurs first.
I11(h) The validity of a test report for a reference insulated body shall expire at the end of a period of three years, or at the end of the manufacture of 1,000 serially-produced bodies, whichever occurs first.
I11(i) Serially-produced equipment shall be produced or assembled by the same manufacturer and at the same manufacturing plant as the reference equipment.
I11(j) Identical mechanical refrigerating appliances shall be manufactured by the same manufacturer and at the same manufacturing plant as the reference mechanical refrigerating appliance.
I11(k) Serially-produced bodies shall be manufactured by the same manufacturer and at the same manufacturing plant as the reference insulated body.
I11(l) Equipment manufacturers shall notify the ATP manager 30 days before start of manufacture so that the ATP manager or other representative of the Administrator may observe the manufacturing operation. 
I11(m) Owners who receive a U.S. ATP certificate have the responsibility to manitain the equipment in good repair and operating condition with the understanding that the certificate is valid only so long as:
I11(1) The insulated body and the thermal appliance are maintained in good condition; 
I11(2) No material alteration is made to the thermal appliance which decreases its refrigerating capacity, and; 
I11(3) If the thermal appliance is replaced, it is replaced by an appliance of equal or greater refrigerating capacity. 

I80�1A3300.61
I89Testing and verification requirements. 
I11In accordance with ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 1, 1(a), 2(a), 2(b), 2(c) and 3, and Appendix 2, paragraph 41, certification of new equipment is based upon the following: 
I11(a) For a unit of equipment, a test of the equipment in an approved testing station. 
I11(b) For serially-produced equipment: 
I11(1) A test of one unit of equipment in an approved testing station, such unit to serve as the reference equipment. 
I11(2) Verification that production of other units of equipment is in conformity with the reference equipment. 
I11(c) For mechanically refrigerated equipment, certification may be based upon a separate test of the mechanical refrigerating appliance and a separate test of the insulated body. 

I80�1A3300.64
I89Application for certificate for new equipment produced or assembled in the United States or in a foreign country which is not a contracting party to the ATP. 
I11Application for certification shall be submitted to the ATP manager by an officer in the organization of the owner of the equipment. In the case of equipment manufactured in the United States, application may be made by an officer in the organization of the equipment manufacturer, acting on behalf of the owner. Copies of the Form, Application for U.S. ATP Certificate for New Equipment Produced or Assembled in the United States or in a Foreign Country Which is not a Contracting Party to the ATP, may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. The following information must be supplied in the application: 
I11(a) A statement whether the owner is a domestic owner or a foreign owner, with the name, address and telephone �240�number of its principal office, and the name and title of person to contact. 
I11(b) If the operator of the equipment is different from the owner, the name and address of the operator. 
I11(c) Type of equipment (intermodal freight container, semi-trailer, trailer, railcar, or truck). 
I11(d) Total number of units of equipment. 
I11(e) Definition and distinguishing mark of the equipment for which certification is sought, referring to ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3 and Appendix 4. 
I11(f) Name, address, and telephone number of the principal office of the equipment manufacturer, and name and title of the person to contact. 
I11(g) Name and address of the plant at which the equipment was manufactured. 
I11(h) In the case of a unit of equipment (i.e., the insulated body with its mechanical refrigerating appliance installed) that has been tested to serve as the reference equipment for serially-produced equipment: 
I11(1) The original or certified true copy of the test report for the reference equipment. 
I11(2) For the serially-produced equipment: 
I11(i) The manufacturer's make and model number for the equipment, including a brief description of the equipment and enclosure of any brochure on the equipment which might be available. 
I11(ii) The basis upon which the equipment meets the definition of serially-produced equipment, with respect to the reference equipment. 
I11(iii) A statement that the equipment was manufactured at the same plant at which the reference equipment was manufactured. 
I11(iv) A statement that production of the equipment was in conformity with the reference equipment.
I11(i) In the case where the mechanical refrigerating appliance and the insulated body have been tested separately:
I11(1) For the reference mechanical refrigerating appliance:
I11(i) The original or certified true copy of the test report.
I11(ii) From the test report, the effective refrigerating capacity, W, in watts, of the appliance at an outside temperature of +30 G6T1�G1T1C and the inside temperature (T3seeG1T1 ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3 and Appendix 4) for the class of equipment for which certification is sought. ``W'' must be equal to, or greater than, the increased heat transfer rate, HG5T2iG1T1, for the reference insulated body. See paragraph (3)(iii) below.
I11(2) For the identical mechanical refrigerating appliances:
I11(i) Name and address of the plant at which the identical appliances and reference appliance were manufactured.
I11(ii) The manufacturer's make, model number, and a brief description of the appliances with enclosure of any brochure on the appliances which might be available.
I11(iii) A statement that the appliances meet the definition of identical mechanical refrigerating appliances.
I11(3) For the reference insulated body:
I11(i) The original or certified true copy of the test report.
I11(ii) The total heat transfer rate of the body, HG5T2tG1T1=S�0AK�0AG6T1DG1T1 T, in watts, where: ``S'' is the mean surface area of the body, from the test report; ``K'' is the heat transfer coefficient of the body, from the test report; and, ``G6T1DG1T1 T'' is the difference in degrees Kelvin between an outside temperature of +30 G6T1�G1T1C and the inside temperature for the class of equipment for which certification is sought.
I11(iii) The increased beat transfer rate, HG5T2iG1T1, obtained by multiplying the total heat transfer rate HG5T2tG1T1, by the factor of 1.75.
I11(4) For the serially-produced insulated bodies:
I11(i) Name and address of the plant at which the serially-produced bodies and reference body were manufactured.
I11(ii) The manufacturer's make, model number, and a brief description of the bodies, with any brochure on the bodies which might be available.
I11(iii) The basis upon which the bodies meet the definition of serially-produced bodies, with respect to the reference insulated body.
I11(iv) A statement that production of the bodies was in conformity with the reference insulated body.
I11(j) Information on the equipment after manufacture:
�241�I11(1) A statement that each mechanical refrigerating appliance, after it was installed in the body, was operated and thoroughly checked and that each appliance functioned properly.
I11(2) A statement that each body and each appliance has affixed to it a manufacturer's plate or other means of identification which shows the items of information required by ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 6.
I11(3) A statement that each unit of equipment, before it is put into service, will have affixed to it a certification plate and distinguishing mark as specified in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 4 and 5, and Appendixes 3 and 4.
I11(4) A list showing, for each unit of equipment, the serial number of the body and the corresponding owner's equipment identification number.

I80�1A3300.67 
I89Application for certificate for new equipment produced or assembled in a foreign country which is a contracting party to the ATP. 
I11An application for certification of equipment shall be submitted to the ATP manager by an officer in the organization of the owner of the equipment. Copies of the Form, Application for U.S. ATP Certificate for New Equipment Produced or Assembled in a Foreign Country Which is a Contracting Party, may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. The following information must be submitted in the application: 
I11(a) A statement that the owner is a domestic owner, with the name, address and telephone number of its principal office, and the name and title of the person to contact. 
I11(b) If the operator of the equipment is different from the owner, the name and address of the operator. 
I11(c) The type of equipment (intermodal freight container, trailer, semi-trailer, railcar, or truck.) 
I11(d) Total number of units of equipment. 
I11(e) Definition of the equipment for which certification is sought, referring to ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3, and Appendix 4. 
I11(f) Name, address, and telephone number of the manufacturer of the equipment, and the name and title of the person to contact. 
I11(g) The manufacturer's make and model number for the equipment, including a brief description of the equipment and any brochure on the equipment which might be available. 
I11(h) The original or certified true copy of the test report for the reference equipment. 
I11(i) The original or certified true copy of the Foreign-ATP certificate issued for the equipment. 
I11(j) A statement that each unit of equipment, before it is put into service, will have affixed to it a certification plate and distinguishing mark as specified in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 4 and 5, and Appendixes 3 and 4. 
I11(k) A list showing, for each unit of equipment, the serial number of the body and the corresponding owner's equipment identification number. 

I80�1A3300.70 
I89Issuance of certificate. 
I11The ATP manager will evaluate the documents received and, for equipment deemed qualified, will issue a U.S. ATP certificate to the applicant within 30 days of the receipt of an application and any relevant information required. The certificate will be in the format prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 3. For equipment deemed not qualified, the applicant will be advised of the reasons for non-qualification within 30 days of the receipt of an application and any relevant information required. 

I80�1A3300.73 
I89Period of validity of certificates. 
I11In accordance with ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 1(a) and 1(b), certificates issued for new equipment are valid for a period of 6 years from date of issue. 

I56Subpart G_Certification of Equipment in Service 

I80�1A3300.76 
I89General. 
I11Only domestic owners are eligible to receive U.S. ATP certificates for equipment in service, with certification based upon the following: 
I11(a) For equipment which has not previously been certified: 
I11(1) For each unit of equipment, a test in a U.S. ATP testing station or in a testing station located in and approved by a country which is a Contracting �242�Party, to measure the K-coefficient of the insulated body and the efficiency of the thermal appliance in accordance with �1A3300.10 and �1A3300.13 of this rule. 
I11(2) If the equipment consists of serially-produced equipment manufactured by a particular equipment manufacturer, and belonging to one owner, certification may be based upon the following: 
I11(i) A test of 1 percent of the units of equipment as prescribed in preceding paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the units tested to serve as reference equipment.
I11(ii) An inspection of each unit of equipment, using the procedures set forth in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2, paragraphs 29 and 49. The inspections shall be performed by one of the following, at the choice of the owner: 
I11(A) Persons in the owner's organization whom the owner deems qualified to perform inspections, or; 
I11(B) By an independent inspection agency which the owner deems competent to perform inspections. Fees charged by such inspection agency shall be payable directly to the agency by the owner. 
I11(iii) A report of each inspection shall be completed on a form corresponding to the pertinent test report model in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 2. Report forms may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. 
I11(b) For renewal of a U.S. ATP certificate which is nearing its expiration date, any of the following three procedures: 
I11(1) For each unit of equipment, a test as prescribed in preceding paragraph (a)(1) of this section, or; 
I11(2) If the equipment is serially-produced by a particular manufacturer and belongs to one owner, test and inspection of the equipment according to the procedures prescribed in preceding paragraphs (a)(2)(i), (ii), and (iii) of this section, or; 
I11(3) An inspection of each unit of equipment as prescribed in paragraphs (a)(2)(ii) and (iii) of this section. 
I11(c) For equipment which is currently certified according to a U.S. ATP certificate, and which has been transferred from one domestic owner to another, the new owner may obtain a U.S. ATP certificate by submitting the original or certified true copy of the certificate issued to the previous owner, and by performing an inspection and submitting an inspection report for each unit of equipment. 
I11(d) For equipment which is currently certified according to a Foreign-ATP certificate, and which has been transferred from a foreign owner to a domestic owner, the domestic owner may obtain a U.S. ATP certificate by submitting the original or certified true copy of the test report for the reference equipment and the original or certified true copy of the foreign certificate, and by performing an inspection and submitting an inspection report for each unit of equipment. 
I11(e) Owners who receive a U.S. ATP certificate have the responsibility to maintain equipment in good repair and operating condition with the understanding that the certificate is valid only so long as: 
I11(1) The insulated body and the thermal appliance are maintained in good condition; 
I11(2) No material alteration is made to the thermal appliance which decreases its refrigeration capacity, and; 
I11(3) If the thermal appliance is replaced, it is replaced by an appliance of equal or greater refrigerating capacity. 

I80�1A3300.79 
I89Application for certificate. 
I11An application shall be submitted to the ATP manager by an officer in the organization of the owner of the equipment. Copies of the Form, Application for U.S. ATP Certificate for Equipment in Service, may be obtained by a request to the ATP manager. The following information is requested in the application: 
I11(a) A statement that the owner is a domestic owner, with the name, address, and telephone number of its principal office, and name and title of person to contact. 
I11(b) If the operator of the equipment is different from the owner, the name and address of the operator. 
I11(c) The type of equipment (intermodal freight container, trailer, semi-trailer, railcar, or truck). 
I11(d) The total number of units of equipment. 
�243�I11(e) The definition of the equipment for which certification is sought, referring to ATP, Annex 1, paragraph 3 and Appendix 4. 
I11(f) For equipment which has not been previously certified, one of the following:
I11(1) For each unit of equipment, the original or certified true copy of the test report, or; 
I11(2) If the equipment is serially-produced by one manufacturer: 
I11(i) Name of manufacturer. 
I11(ii) The original or certified true copy of the test report(s) of 1 percent of the equipment which was tested to serve as reference equipment. 
I11(iii) A report of inspection for each unit of equipment. 
I11(g) For renewal of a U.S. ATP Certificate which is nearing its expiration date: 
I11(1) The original or certified true copy of that certificate, and; 
I11(2) One of the following, (i) (ii), or (iii): 
I11(i) For each unit of equipment, the original or certified true copy of the test report. 
I11(ii) If the equipment is serially-produced by one manufacturer: 
I11(A) Name of manufacturer. 
I11(B) The original or certified true copy of the test report(s) of 1 percent of the equipment which was tested to serve as reference equipment. 
I11(C) A report of inspection from each unit of equipment. 
I11(iii) A report of inspection for each unit of equipment. 
I11(h) For equipment which is currently certified according to a U.S. ATP certificate, and which has been transferred from one domestic owner to another: 
I11(1) The original or certified true copy of that certificate. 
I11(2) A report of inspection for each unit of equipment. 
I11(i) For equipment which is currently certified according to a Foreign-ATP certificate, and which has been transferred from a foreign owner to a domestic owner: 
I11(1) The original or certified true copy of the test report for the reference equipment. 
I11(2) The original or certified true copy of the Foreign-ATP certificate. 
I11(3) A report of inspection for each unit of equipment. 
I11(j) A statement that each unit of equipment has, or will have, affixed to it a certification plate and distinguishing mark as prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 4 and 5, and Appendices 3 and 4. 
I11(k) A list showing, for each unit of equipment, the serial number of the body and the corresponding owner's equipment identification number. 

I80�1A3300.82
I89Issuance of certificate. 
I11The ATP manager will evaluate documents received and, for equipment deemed qualified, will issue a U.S. ATP certificate to the applicant within 30 days of receipt of the application and any relevant information required. The certificate will be in the format prescribed in ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 3. For equipment deemed not qualified, the applicant will be advised of reasons for non-qualification within 30 days of receipt of an application and any relevant information required. 

I80�1A3300.85
I89Period of validity of certificates. 
I11In accordance with ATP, Annex 1, Appendix 1, paragraphs 1(b), and Appendix 2, paragraphs 29(c) and 49(b) and (d), considered in combination, certificates will be valid for periods as follows: 
I11(a) For equipment which passes a test, 6 years. 
I11(b) For serially-produced equipment of which 1 percent have passed a test, and all units have been inspected and passed such inspection, 6 years. 
I11(c) For renewal of a U.S. ATP certificate which is nearing its expiration date, where the equipment has passed an inspection but has not been tested, 3 years. 
I11(d) For equipment currently certified according to a U.S. ATP certificate, where the equipment has been transferred from one domestic owner to another and the equipment has passed an inspection, 3 years or the date of expiration of the current U.S. ATP certificate, whichever gives the later expiration date on the new U.S. ATP certificate. 
�244�I11(e) For equipment currently certified according to a Foreign-ATP certificate, where the equipment has been transferred from a foreign owner to a domestic owner and the equipment has passed an inspection, 3 years or the date of expiration of the foreign certificate, whichever gives the later expiration date on the newly issued U.S. ATP certificate. 

I56Subpart H_Other Provisions 

I80�1A3300.88 
I89Fees for U.S. ATP certificates. 
I11The fee schedule for issuance of U.S. ATP certificates by the U.S. Department of Agriculture will be calculated according to the criteria in Circular A�0925�1A\2\N, issued by the Office of Management and Budget. Fees may be revised as required on an annual basis. 

I28N\2\�1AA copy of Circular A�0925 can be obtained by a request to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), 17th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue, NW., Washington, DC 20503. 


I80�1A3300.91
I89List of approved testing stations, approved testing laboratories, and fees for certificates. 
I11A current list of U.S. ATP testing stations, U.S. ATP testing laboratories, and fees for issuance of U.S. ATP certificates may be obtained by request to the ATP manager. 

I80�1A3300.94 
I89Appeals. 
I11Any organization aggrieved by an action in connection with this rule may obtain a review of such action by submitting pertinent information by letter to the Administrator. The decision of the Administrator is the final agency action.
